body:
I’m newer to Christianity. I studied a lot about existentialism and buddhism/nonduality/taoism / general spirituality before Jesus came for me. 

Finding Ecclesiastes was mind blowing for me. I think I get the gist of it (life sucks, fear God, do good and enjoy life when you can), but I’m sure I’m missing a lot of context and inspired takes. 

School me. Thanks

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

> life sucks, fear God, do good and enjoy life when you can

That's pretty much it. Everything is absolutely hopeless and devoid of meaning in this present world, the atheists and nihilists are actually right about that. That's why it's foolish to put so much stock in it, as it's not only unfair but will not last.

body: I was researching it more last night. I loved reading Tolstoy’s take on nihilism and meaninglessness. Apparently Tolstoy was very touched by Ecclesiastes. He determined that life is meaningless without God, and by his logical process he arrived at the conclusion that God must exist.

body: I'm not a Paulian, there's lots of works forged in his name too, especially those abominations called 1 & 2 Timothy and Titus, which are obvious attempts by the Romans to insert traditional pagan beliefs into Christianity. I in fact get annoyed seeing everyone treat Paul as important as Jesus, if not *more* important in many cases. But what is clear is that the epistle of "James" barely mentions Jesus at all and teaches a works gospel, something clearly opposed in all four gospels as well as Paul. Actually that goes for the Old Testament too, despite the increased presence of earthly punishment.
